solution_line_template: After {time_elapsed} minutes, the second runner has traveled {time_elapsed}/{second_runner_pace} = <<{time_elapsed}/{second_runner_pace}={second_runner_distance}>>{second_runner_distance} miles.
Similarly, the first runner has traveled {time_elapsed}/{first_runner_pace} = <<{time_elapsed}/{first_runner_pace}={first_runner_distance}>>{first_runner_distance} miles.

Therefore, the two runners are {second_runner_distance} - {first_runner_distance} = <<{second_runner_distance}-{first_runner_distance}={distance_apart}>>{distance_apart} mile apart when the second runner stops.
Thus, the second runner can stop for a maximum of {first_runner_pace} minutes, which is the amount of time it takes the first runner to travel {distance_apart} mile.
